      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(Shape s)
        Implementation of the compareTo method derived from "implements Comparable" The Comparable interface is used to define the "natural ordering" of classes. That is, the default way to sort objects of a class. If we want to sort a list of shapes, Java has no way to know inherently if one shape should come before or after another shape. Thus, we use Comparable to tell Java how to sort a list. Comparable just provides a default way to sort objects. Most methods that attempt to sort or order any collection of objects will use objects implementing the comparable interface (e.g. Collections.sort()). It is possible to define other ordering or provide a way to compare objects without the comparable interface as well. This is demonstrated with the ShapeComparator, which defines an alternate ordering for shapes. You will notice that the driver sorts a list of shapes with both: (a) The Shape class's "Natural Order". i.e. it's compareTo method. Collections.sort(list); (b) An alternate order, as defined by the shapecomparator class. Collections.sort(list, new ShapeComparator()); For this compareTo, we compare area and perimeter to determine how to sort, but in general any property of the object could be used. By convention, when comparing two objects, a comparison should return -1 if the first object in the comparison should come before the second object in a sorted list, 0 if they are effectively equal, and 1 if the first object should come after the second object in a sorted list. A comparison may sort elements in ascending order, but may be defined to sort data in any way. This compareTo orders shapes by area and perimeter. If a shape has a larger perimeter, it should be ordered to come after the shape it is compared to in a sorted list. If the areas are equal, the shape with the smaller area comes first. A list of shapes is thus sorted in ascending order of perimeter/area when using Shape's compareTo. E.g. we have the shapes A, B, and C. A has a larger perimeter than B and an equal perimeter to C. A also has a smaller area than C. A.compareTo(B) yields 1 to indicate that it should come after B in a sorted list. This is because we define that shapes with larger perimeters (A) should be placed after shapes with smaller perimeters (B). A.compareTo(C) yields -1 to indicate that it should come before C in a sorted list. This is because the perimeters are equal, but we define that shapes with larger areas (A) should be placed after shapes with smaller areas (C). Thus, the when using compareTo to sort, a list will be sorted as such: B C A
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<Shape>
        Returns:
        -1, 0, or 1. These values are returned on the following conditions: (this refers to this Shape object, and s refers to the input parameter Shape s) (1) Perimeter of this is > perimeter of s: return 1 (this should come after s in a sorted list) (2) Perimeter of this is < perimeter of s: return -1 (this should come before s in a sorted list) (3) Perimeter of this = perimeter of s: (a) Area of this is > area of s: return 1 (this should come after s in a sorted list) (b) Area of this is < area of s: return -1 (this should come before s in a sorted list) (C) Area of this = area of s: return 0 (this is effecitively equal to s in a sorted list)

      • getId

        public java.lang.String getId()
        Gets the shape's id.
        Returns:
        The name id of the shape.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        toString override. Gives information about the shape. You will need to use the methods getShapeType(), getArea(), and getPerimeter() to complete the output string. Note that these are abstract methods in Shape and are thus not implemented here. Instead, when you call getShapeType() in this method, it will use the getShapeType() method as implemented in the non-abstract shape that the toString() is called on. E.g. you call toString() on a Square. The Square does not have its own toString, so it looks for a toString of one of its superclasses. Shape is the first superclass of Square that has a toString, so the toString of Shape is used. getShapeType() is overriden and implemented in Square, so the Shape toString() uses the getShapeType() as defined in Square, which should return the String "Square".
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        A String describing the Shape. The returned string is of the format: "<>\t ID = <>\t area = <>\t perimeter = <>" Where <> should be replaced with the value of x described inside the angle brackets. \t is the tab character.
